lines.text:
[after he learns that Trent ignored the sexual advances of Miriam]
No respectable gentleman is THAT respectable.
Why did you conceive, plan and execute this dastardly and scandalous crime?
I wanted the money.
[the court spectators roar with laughter]

[to "Clean Willy"]
If you've turned nose on me, I'll see you in lavender.

[Admiring Miriam]
That's what I call a proper woman - which that is to say - not proper at all.
[first lines]

[narration]
In the year 1855, England and France were at war with Russia in the Crimea. The English troops were paid in gold. Once a month, twenty-five thousand pounds in gold was loaded into strongboxes inside the London bank of Huddleston and Bradford and taken by trusted armed guards to the railway station. The convoy followed no fixed route or timetable. At the station, the gold was loaded into the luggage van of the Folkestone train for shipment to the coast and from there to the Crimea. The strongboxes were placed into two specially-built Chubb safes constructed of three-quarter inch tempered steel. Each safe weighed five hundred and fifty pounds. Each safe was fitted with two locks, requiring two keys, or four keys altogether. For security, each key was individually protected. Two keys were entrusted to the railway dispatcher who kept them locked in his office. A third was in the custody of Mr. Edgar Trent, president of the Huddleston and Bradford. And the fourth key was given to Mr. Henry Fowler, manager of the Huddleston and Bradford. The presence of so much gold in one place naturally aroused the interest of the English criminal elements. But in 1855 there had never been a robbery from a moving railway train.
[Edward Pierce arrives from on top of the train]
You look a sight.
*I* look a sight?
You're all covered in soot.

[aghast]
It's the smoke! I haven't brought a change!
Well, that's bloody brilliant!
[Edward Pierce looks at Agar's clothes]

[realizing what Pierce intends]
No! Oh, no! You pick me clean, you put me in a coffin with a rotten, stinking cat, and now you strip me bollock naked.
Do you ever tell anyone the truth?
The truth? The truth... no.
All you ever think about is money.
All anyone ever thinks about is money.

[referring to the London Bridge Station train dispatcher's office]
What's your pogue up there, anyway?
Two Chubb keys in that green cupboard.
What might they be, them keys?
Two keys that I happen to want.

[turns to look at Pierce]
We're partners, aren't we? Of course, if you're trying to say that you don't trust me completely...

[turns and looks at Agar]
I don't trust you at all.

[smiles and nods]
Good.

[He's just realized Pierce is planning to heist the Crimean gold shipment]
You're out of your bloody mind, Pierce, trying to rob a moving train! It can't be done!
Why not?
Well... it hasn't been done, has it?
No.

[to Agar]
Find me a dead cat!
What exactly are you constructing?
We thought a water wheel. It will be so delightful, especially when there will be the rusted curve of the water wheel itself. Don't you agree?
We are building the rusted wheel at considerable expense.
It is constructed of previously rusted metal, the craftsmen are most ingenious. And of course we must wait for the weeds to grow up around the site before it takes on the proper appearance.
Oh I'm sure it'll be a handsome ruin.
Where is Elizabeth?
I have passed many pleasant hours here, watching the workman fit each piece into its precise slot. Such skill!
They screw it together do they?
No, bolt it actually. With long bolts, fitted tightly.
Yes. *Long* bolts, fitted tightly.
I've just returned from America, a country of many prominent erections.
It *is* exciting to see things come together, so long as the quality does not suffer.
Tight-fitting joints, that's the secret.
It's *so* rare these days.

[It]
depends on the skill of the workman, of course.
And he *must* have the proper tools.
You didn't do the Barclay Hills job, did you?
Barclay Hills? Shit job!

[They're at the train station about to do the "Jolly Gaff" to get the two keys]
Where's the chavvy?
There.
[He nods towards a boy street urchin]
He's your son.
I don't have no son!
Louisa says he's your son.

[snorts a laugh]
Louisa! She wouldn't know, would she? IS THAT HIM? He's not my son! He's too ugly to be my son!
What's the sweetener?
A guinea.

]
Well, if he is my son he'll be worth it.
It's all very good... unless something goes wrong.
What could go wrong?

[to Clean Willy]
If you've turned nose on me, I'll see you in lavender!

[referring to Pierce's social acquaintances while she disrobes in front of him]
And do they know you take an *interest* in the theater?
Well, an unmarried gentleman must amuse himself.

[smiling]
Must he?
